newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan traders may re-export Thai rubber to China.
newsitem.headline: Japan traders may re-export Thai rubber to China.

text.p: Some Japanese traders are considering re-exporting around 1,000 tonnes of Thai benchmark Ribbed Smoked Sheet (RSS3) to China in an attempt to reduce bumper rubber stocks here, traders said on Wednesday.
"One trade house in Japan, which took around 500 tonnes of rubber at the October spot expiry, was believed to have sold the rubber to China," one market source said.
The trade house is likely to sell an additional 500 tonnes to China after November's spot expiry later this month.
Japanese traders said re-exporting was profitable due to lower prices for rubber here relative to those in producing countries.

"Considering the fact domestic rubber prices are currently lower by about 17-18 yen per kg compared with those in Thailand, re-exporting can be profitable despite the high export costs," another trader said.
Traders said more Japanese traders may be trying to intentionally cut bumper rubber stocks in Japan in an attempt to prop up the market.
Japanese rubber stocks at designated warehouses totalled 47,520 tonnes as of October 20, the highest level since September 1990, the Rubber Trade Association of Japan said.
The high rubber stocks have cast a shadow on domestic rubber futures markets in recent months.
Since the benchmark rubber contract on the Tokyo Commodity Exchange (TOCOM) hit 166.90 yen per kg at the end of last May, the market has been in a downward trend.

The benchmark hit this year's low of 131.10 yen on October 7. The current benchmark April contract on TOCOM ended the morning session at 142.7 yen on Wednesday. -- Tokyo Commodity Desk +81-3-3432-7431
